We have shareholder visitation later in the conference, and we'll probably be seeing many of you. So thank you very much, for joining us today, and enjoy the rest of the conference.

headline: Northeast Utilities, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you for joining us this morning. I'm sure when you got the e-mail last week saying we were going to be moving our breakfast to 6:45, you all stood up and cheered. But we appreciate you joining us at this very early hour, though I think folks i
componenttext:
Well, thank you for joining us this morning. I'm sure when you got the e-mail last week saying we were going to be moving our breakfast to 6:45, you all stood up and cheered. But we appreciate you joining us at this very early hour, though I think folks in the east coast it may not [indiscernible] quite that early. I'm Jeff Kotkin, I'm Vice President of Investor Relations for Northeast Utilities. And what I want to do is introduce some of the folks in the room from our company, from NSTAR NU, who won't be speaking, and then we'll go to the Safe Harbor and then I'll turn it over to the company CEO. 
So let me start, John Valera from NSTAR, is sitting in the front row here. I represent as IR and also financial reporting. NSTAR Treasurer, Phil Lembo, is right over here. Randy Shoop, the NU Treasurer is over here. And Sue Weber, our Assistant Treasurer, is right over there. So again, thank you very much for joining us this early morning. We're really excited about this presentation, and we hope you are as well. I'm just going go through a little bit in terms of Safe Harbor, and this for the folks who are on the webcast because this is being webcast. 
This presentation includes statements concerning our expectations, beliefs, plans, objectives, goals, strategy, and assumption for future events and future financial performance or growth and other statements that are not historic facts. These statements are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. We have some Safe Harbor slides on the merger in the front of the deck and before each company's financial presentation, we also have Safe Harbor in there. So we urge you to take a look of that.
So with that, again, thank you very much, and I just want to turn this presentation now over to Chuck Shivery, NU's Chairman, President and CEO.

headline: Northeast Utilities, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jeff, thank you. Thank you for joining us. This is a somewhat early hour. But we have a multi-faceted presentation for you today. We're trying to do a number of things, the first and probably, the foremost, of course, is Tom and I would like to spend a li
componenttext:
Jeff, thank you. Thank you for joining us. This is a somewhat early hour. But we have a multi-faceted presentation for you today. We're trying to do a number of things, the first and probably, the foremost, of course, is Tom and I would like to spend a little more time talking about the merger. We've had a lot of conversations since we announced it, but there are some questions that some of you have asked. We'll try to hit those head on today, but clearly, we'll both be around for a few days and give you the opportunity to talk to us privately, if you'd like.
The second thing is we both had our earnings releases out. You saw that the third quarter for both companies was very good. NU also increased its guidance for 2010. And so, we'll get this later on in the presentation. We'll have Dave McHale and Jim Muntz talk a little bit about the respective quarters for each of our companies.
And for NU, I know a lot of you view this morning as a way to get updated on [indiscernible] on some of our major projects. So when Tom and I get finished talking a little bit about the merger, Lee's going to spend some time giving you an update on the status and on the capital expenditures around some of the major projects. So that's what we're going to try to accomplish today. Please ask questions as you get the opportunity because we really would like to have this discussion.
So if you go to Page 5. We've spent a lot of time talking to a number of you privately, but this really is a compelling combination. And I would tell you that I have not met anyone that hasn't said, logically, this makes sense. This strategic for the industrial logic its [ph] combination is compelling. We think it's going to be a tremendously exciting new company at closure. We talked about closure being nine to 12 months away. You'll here Tom being a little bit optimistic about, let's try to do it in nine months. I think we can actually accomplish that, and I think that's where we should be headed. We have a significant transformation opportunity to Nu. We've talked to you about those over the last number of years, and we combine that we the balance, strength that we have with NSTAR and the cash flow, it allows us to really expand on those projects in a way that is more effective from a financial standpoint.
This new company is larger. It will be the 15th to the 17th largest utility in the country, depending on how you measure it. And it is more diverse and much better positioned to support the economic growth and renewables in New England. I think, and you have heard me say this before, New England is an inflection point. They've got Reg E requirements. They've got RPS requirements. And if you play those out over the next few years, we need to do something to make that happen. I think this new company is going to be positioned in a way that it will be able to help make that happen for the benefit of not only our stockholders but for the benefit of the customers and for the region. This is clearly accretive to earnings in year one, and we think provides not only increased earnings and dividend potential but an enhanced total shareholder return. The service quality capabilities are enhanced. It is the largest customer base in New England. You've seen the map many, many times that shows the low centers in New England. It's Boston, it's Connecticut. As the two companies have a significant portion of that New England population. 
And then a highly experienced and complementary leadership team with a proven track record. You've heard us talk a lot about the similarities of these two companies. We've worked together for a number of years. Restoration, as we've had storms. We’ve sent crews to NSTAR, NSTAR has sent crews to our service territories. So we've worked together. We know how that works. And the Hydro-Québec project is just one more example, and probably the most recent example, of the two companies working together. And I think as that proven track record showed, this then becomes the next logical step in that process.
If you go to the next slide. You've seen this before. We expect to close in nine to 12 months. Dual headquarters in both Hartford and Boston. Tom will spend a little bit more time talking about that. NU will be the company's name, the consideration is 100% NU shares. The exchange ratio, as you can see, is 1.312. Shares for NU per NSTAR share is split about $56.44 [ph]. The dividend increase will be about a 20% increase for NU shareholders. And [indiscernible] for NSTAR shareholders, and from a government standpoint, I will become the non-Executive Chairman at this point of closure. Tom will be president and CEO. There will be 14 board members. Tom and I will each be on the board, and there will be six independent members from each one of our existing companies.
So as you look at this, this truly is a merger of equals. And we think you'll see that from the government standpoint, from the management standpoint, from just about any perspective, this is just as balanced as an entity can be.
Specific benefits to NU shareholders, we’ve talked about approximately 20% dividend increase. That number’s about right. It can vary by two or three percentage points, whether you calculate it today or whether you calculate it on what you project it to be at the time of closer. The cash flow increased to eliminate the equity issuance. We talk to you from NU standpoint, about the fact that we expected to have about $300 million equity issuance in 2012. Essentially, that equity issuance goes away. And for the foreseeable future, as we look at our five-year plan, we don't see any equity issuance in that plan.
Likely credit upgrades, obviously, the benefit of reduction in debt issuance and lower interest rates, we think that will be helpful. Increased market liquidity, a number of you have difficult times buying either us or NSTAR because of the size of the organization. So if we put these two together, the market liquidity obviously expands dramatically and gives you the opportunity to buy shares in a much larger company. Increased opportunities to reduce cost over time, and this is one of those things that you ask us a lot. And this takes the form of many different kinds of questions, but it is basically [ph] of synergy. And if you could tell us exactly how much there is in day one, day two and day three, that would be appreciated also.
But this merger is not predicated on synergies. It's predicated on providing growth to the region and being able to, in a way that neither one of us can right now, answer questions and provide solutions for our customers. That ultimately will help the shareholders of this combined company.
Now clearly if we do that, there will be opportunities for improvement in the effectiveness of these organizations. There will be a change in the composition of some of our employees, but we would expect to handle most of that through voluntary attrition and through retirement. There will be best practices. There will benefits of putting these large systems that we have together. So there will be the ability to reduce cost over time, and that will flow to the benefit of not only the customers but also of our shareholders. And as I said earlier, the ability to achieve a higher earnings growth rate.
We have talked to you about it being accretive. We probably didn't give you the exact numbers on each of one of these. We're going to point out some of the things to take us from somewhere in the 6% to 9% growth rate that we previously were to something toward the upper end of that 6% to 9% growth rate. Obviously, the additional shares are negative to that. But for that, we get NSTAR's earnings growth, which is significant. We get the avoidance of the equity issuance that we just talked about, lower financing costs, less current parent debt and the implementation of best practices. So as we look across the spectrum for the next few years, there are going to be many real benefit to this merger in a way that will allow us to increase our earnings and ultimately our dividends at a rate that was higher than we thought we could do before and certainly at a rate that's higher that either one of the stand-alone companies.
Let's take it back about, probably two or three years now. We had a conversation with one of these leading about the [indiscernible] standard and about Reg E and about what we saw as the inability of Connecticut and the region to meet those standards if something didn't happen. What ultimately came out of that is the Hydro-Québec project. And as you know, we've made significant progress on that, and this is probably the first time that we've been able to say, "We actually signed that thing," as opposed to, "Trust us, it's moving along well." It's hard to know exactly what the future is going to be like. And sometimes we look at the future in a static environment, and we don't think that it as dynamic. Three years ago, we wouldn't have talked about Hydro-Québec. Now it is becoming a reality, and it is a business model, it's a participant pay model that may be the kind of model that allows us to deal with some of these larger renewable issues in the future. 
This slide is simply something that we talked to you before. We called it the consortium. It's really a group of four companies, NSTAR, United Illuminating, National Grid and ourselves, that are making progress on this project. It's not complete yet, and there's still a lot of work to do, but it's gone past the conceptual stage. So as we look at the possibility of bringing onshore wind [ph], typically in northern New Hampshire and in Maine, down into the low centers, this kind of project has a real possibility. 250 to 300 miles long, probably 1,600 megawatts, something around $1.5 billion in cost and a participant pay model that may allow us to bundle the generation and the transmission together and make that available to the load centers in the region. We'll talk to you more about this as it continues down the path. But this is a real project that we think we will be able to move forward. It's not in the five-year financial plans right now. But it is something, clearly, that we think this new company will be able to do in a way that's better than either one of our existing companies. 
And then the last slide is the Northern Pass, or the Hydro-Québec project. We own 75%, NSTAR owns 25%. It's closing, obviously. So the new company just owns [ph] 100 percent. 1,200 megawatts of transfer capability. We have announced the Southern terminus [ph], which is Franklin, New Hampshire. The northern part, obviously, is a Concept [ph] station in Québec. We gave you an update on the cost of that project, it's about $1.1 billion now. The TSA was signed on October 4. The permitting process started on the 14th with the U.S. application for the DOE. PPAs are under discussion and we’ll probably be filing the project with FERC -- not probably, we will be filing the project with FERC this quarter, probably in the month of November.
So that project is moving along. I know you've had a number of questions, and we kept saying, “This is moving along, we will get there,” and, in fact, signing the TSA was a big milestone. We've still a lot of work to do. We've got to get all the approvals. Then we’ve got to get the [indiscernible] approved, we've got to build it. But it's moving along quite nicely, and it really is the kind of project, I think, that can be duplicated elsewhere. It's going to be easier for a company the size of this new company to do this kind of project, I think, than it would have been for us on a stand-alone basis. 
So with that, let me turn it over to Tom.

headline: Northeast Utilities, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2010
componenttextpreview: [ph]Good morning, everyone. I'm losing my voice. A summer cold, I guess, 90 degrees today, they’re saying. But bear with me, and I'll try to make it through. The Hydro-Québec project is something that Chuck thought up many, many years ago, and it kin
componenttext:
[ph]
Good morning, everyone. I'm losing my voice. A summer cold, I guess, 90 degrees today, they’re saying. But bear with me, and I'll try to make it through. The Hydro-Québec project is something that Chuck thought up many, many years ago, and it kind of shows the potential. Laughing, we call it my dowry. He gave 25%, and now he took it back. But here's a project that will reduce the cost of energy in the region, but yet will remove five times the carbon of the infamous Cape Wind project. So it really is a project that moves the needle dramatically from an environmental perspective, but doesn't have a negative impact on our economy. In fact, it helps our economy. So it’s a really exciting project. 
And speaking about an exciting project, how about this merger? I like to tell my employees that I've always been interested in an industry that consolidates. Unfortunately, regulators don't always agree with us the way you should do it. But this is the perfect deal at the right time for both companies. As Chuck said, the whole world of environment and economy have come together, and it needs strong players, not two smaller players, but large and strong players, to help local governments and even national government to figure out an economic and an environmental policy that make sense for our region and the country. So bringing these two companies together is just such an exciting opportunity for us. 
One of the things that, of course, all of our shareholders, Chuck and I spent the first three or four days running every one of our large shareholders just to get a reaction and tell them why we thought this was so exciting. And the reaction has been overwhelming, if you see the way our stock prices have traded for the first two weeks after the announcement. I think it's traded better than any deal that's been in our space for about the last five or 10 years. And we did work very, very hard to create something that was a merger of equals. In fact, I think I will be forever grateful that Chuck is entrusting his shareholders in my hands for some time after the close.
But for the NSTAR shareholders, we really do see an opportunity to use what we have built over the years, which, in my view is [indiscernible] balance sheet to instead of be a company that could financially accelerate its growth, be a company that could invest to accelerate its growth. So it's a perfect combination of using our balance sheet to get the kind of growth that will clearly outperform that in the industry. I think both companies have a great track record of the last few years of outperformance. I think this will ensure that we will outperform for some time to come. And that's important to me, who has a lot of pride in what we've done for our shareholders.
Also, this large footprint. There at one point in time were about six transmission projects, the Green Line that was going to come by sea, one is by sea, one is by land. We had all sorts of projects that we're trying to get these wind power in the north down into the low centers, and every one of them wanted to land in Boston, where we have almost five million people. And so the combination of our load centers in our map and the Northeast Utilities expertise, you all have seen what they have been able to do with their Transmission business over the last few years, really puts us in a unique position to take advantage of it. As Chuck said, we're not exactly sure what's that’s going to the look like, but we do believe that when Lee comes up here and tells you about the Transmission business, that there are things on top of that, that will evolve in the next few years.
One also of the most exciting things, and you'll see it in the slide in a minute, we really are balancing our risk. I really do believe we're creating a lower risk, higher growth opportunity for investors. We really are balancing our regulatory risk between Connecticut, the federal government or FERC, and Massachusetts. And that balance should help us in the long run to really maintain a more consistent and constant earnings growth stream. So we're very excited about what this has in store for our shareholders. 
And speaking of record of delivering on our promises to our shareholders, both companies have a proud history. We've been on a roll. And most importantly, I think that this is going to let us continue that track record which, again, the goal is to outperform the industry. 
The next slide does show this balance in our regulated businesses. And I think that -- I just love this slide because of the way it shows how we at NSTAR will be reducing the all-in-one. We've had a great history in Massachusetts, and we expect that to continue for some time. But to have this kind of balance, I think, does provide the kind of risk profile that will allow us to be very successful going forward.
We put together, Chuck and I have worked diligently. I know many of you can't wait to get your hands on the proxy so you can see about our love story. He wasn't skating in Harvard or anything like that, but we did spend a lot of time together over the last four months. And one of the things that we really were concerned about is putting together the kind of team that would carry on the tradition, that would carry on those return numbers that we just showed a few minutes ago. So we have put a team together, a balanced team. We’re very excited about them. And you can see that we have three and three. Three from a Northeast Utilities background, three from NSTAR backgrounds. And we look forward to working together to create the kind of company that every one of us is proud of.
The timeline, Chuck said I'm very optimistic in this. I've actually challenged my people to get it done in six months. But it all depends on how the election goes tomorrow night as to how quickly we get this done. But there have been an incredible reaction to this transaction from our politicians, our regulators and all of you. It really has been well received, and it's going very well and people want to help us to get on with the game. They really want help us get through the process. There's no one throwing road blocks. There's no one saying this is stupid. And so Chuck and his team spent a lot of time in Connecticut talking to the regulators. It's a one-state approval. Connecticut has said that they don't believe they have any roll in the approval process, so we have to go through Massachusetts Department of Public Utilities. Essentially, that's the critical path to this. And in Massachusetts, we have a no net harm standard, which means we don't have to go through any kind of rate process. In fact, our company is operating under a rate freeze until 2013. So there is no need to talk about rate with respect to this filing. There's lots of history, a lot of precedents for going through and approving mergers, and so we're just looking for a window when the DPU is not too busy. And we can expect, as you can see here, to file probably in November, have hearings in January and then it's up to them as to how quickly they issue an order. And hopefully, that will be on the quicker side.
There's lots of reasons why -- and we at NSTAR have enjoyed a higher multiple in the industry because many of you have looked at us as an investment opportunity, as I mentioned earlier, that's low-risk and high growth. A pretty good combination. But there are lots of characteristics that are responsible for a company having a premier valuation. And I think the slide has just about every single one of those factors that allow companies to be treated differently or special. We seem to have created a company that has every single one of them, whether it's that significant growth prospect that Chuck had mentioned, whether it's the strong earnings and dividend growth prospects, whether it's that diversification of income that we now have that seems so balanced, the management team we put together. I think you can our track records. We care about shareholder returns. That's what drives us. That's what we have delivered for many, many years. And we can do it all with a wonderful cash flow, very, very strong cash flow. We do not need to dilute these earnings going forward.
I'm told that when something is said at this conference, it becomes public information, and you can use it. So I'm going to borrow something. I don't know if Steve Fleishman is here. But I heard him yesterday tell his investors that this is a stock that you all should own. And I honestly believe it. I believe it's the best total return opportunity in this industry.
I'm going to leave it at that and introduce the great Lee Olivier, our Chief Operating Officer, to tell you how he's going to help us to invest all this great cash flow.

headline: Northeast Utilities, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Audio Gap]Because of the merger, but also because of the many accomplishments we've had the course of this past year in terms of our major capital programs. And all of our projects [indiscernible] environmental aspects of it [indiscernible]. But I don'
componenttext:
[Audio Gap]
Because of the merger, but also because of the many accomplishments we've had the course of this past year in terms of our major capital programs. And all of our projects [indiscernible] environmental aspects of it [indiscernible]. But I don't think there's a company that's more for the environment, if not the for the last few years, between the [indiscernible] project, which essentially for the most part shut down all of the major oil, coal-fired power plants that used to how to do it [ph] because of the reliability, obviously the building of the scrubber that's created most of the CO2, not the CO2, but the nitrogen oxide and other pollutants in the air and of course, our solar program in Western Massachusetts, as well as this consortium project that we’re talking about. Really is a major initiative to improve the environment [indiscernible] of our region. So they're good for shareholders, good for customers and good for the environment.
The plans has about $6.6 billion of capital spend. That's up about $200 million over last year's plan. I'll go through that in a few sides. Of note, about Transmission, makes up about half of that capital spend and then you'll see that the transmission CapEx continues to stay strong as we go forward. And as Chuck indicated, there is really no capital in here for any of the transmission that would be built around the consortium project, which could be up in the range of a couple of billion dollars. But as he said, that's a real project. That is moving forward. We'll have more information on that later this year.
When you look at Transmission, we’ve had great success with specifically the new project for the reliability segment in that project. That was a project that we said would cost about $714 million. It's now pegged at $795 million. That is a very, very good price. We received approval, both in Connecticut and in Massachusetts. And we'll start construction on the first major substation of the people [ph] project in the December time frame. We're going to finish up the environmental committee and engineering over the winter. Then we’ll be into full-blown capital construction of that project [ph] lines next year. So we’ll have about a couple of hundred million dollars of CapEx spend next year. That takes a lot of the uncertainty around that project. We are also, in this meeting, we’ll update you on the overall cost of the news project. There’s been a number of changes there. The project [indiscernible] in the Central Connecticut portion of the project shifted out about a year. We'll give you updates on that as well. 
We also are happy with having rate certainty around the deployment of capital in the two big electric company's [indiscernible] about a five-year settlement, [indiscernible] we have a rate case of 2012 and we can probably stretch it a little bit more. But we have certainty around the capital deployment and the recovery of that capital. 
When we look at generation, the Merrimack Scrubber project is really on schedule. It's on the budget. If you remember, we said that project would cost about $547 million. We have now reforecasted that project to be about $430 million. It will still finish on time, in the middle of 2012, but really, just, again, solid progress there as well.
And recently, we completed about 1.8 megawatts of solar at Western Mass Electric. We kind of threw the switch on that last week. We’re going to start about another 4.2 megawatts of solar as part of a $41 million capital plan that we've got previously approved by the Massachusetts DPU. So we’ll have about 6 megawatts of solar in place by the end of 2011, beginning of 2012.
[indiscernible] Gas, another great growth story. Our project, one was the Waterbury pipeline project, about a $67 million project, is almost half complete. It's right on schedule. It's under budget. That's a project that's going to take about two years to connect a lot of customers. We're able to ask customers [ph] interruptible [ph] customers. And we’ve seen a host of other investment opportunities in and around business [ph] in a fairly significant way. And then they put it together with the NSTAR 300,000 driven thousand gas [ph], you've got a gas customer base that's about 500,000 customers, so real growth opportunities. 
[Indiscernible] we’ve kind of covered most of the highlights, the siding decision that we did yet from both Massachusetts and Connecticut was almost exactly what we wanted. We had very few interveners in that project. You see great expectance from the local community and municipal official. Again, start construction on the project in the December timeframe, and the project will be complete in service in 2013. 
Now in the appendix of the presentation is that slide that we always put in there that updates you on each of the three segments and the key milestones, so you can see exactly when those will take place. The Interstate Liability project [ph] [indiscernible] given it’s new for that project earlier this year. We're going to have a meeting late this month with the New England Advisory Committee, where we and our partners, which is National Grid, will present the overall Interstate Reliability project to the past [ph] committee and of course National Grid has [indiscernible] that's over in Rhode Island and in Massachusetts. And as a result of that, we would expect shortly thereafter to see that go ahead from ISO, in which case, we will start deciding of the IRP project [ph] in the third quarter of 2011 for the project to be completed and in service by 2015.
So again, we're very, very positive with the -- escalated the cost of that project which you'll see in the next slide, based upon just the fact that it's shifted out essentially a year. And the Central Connecticut portion of the project is still under review by ISO, and it’s being reviewed again by [ph] prospects of a number of generators that could potentially retire. So those of you that follow New England, in particularly Connecticut, you know that many of the generators there, with the exception of exception of the liquid generated, for the most part, don't run. They [indiscernible] shut down and the revenue proceeds are essentially all around the forward capacity market pricing, and that continues to drop. Every time [indiscernible] 2014 time frame, the floor goes away. We expect that there will be retirement and we would expect also to evaluate those against the market and render a decision on the new date of that project. Now they believe it’s needed, it's just a matter of the timing of the date. We expect to get that by the end of the first quarter or beginning of the second quarter of next year. 
This next slide is kind of a busy slide, but what we wanted to do for you is kind of do the math for you and reconcile the cost of these projects. And as you remember, we've had this $1.49 billion cost of news for some period of time, but as a result of having the final construction cost estimate and the final planning around selling, general and administrative expenses R&T, we escalated that to $795 million. As a result of the other two projects shifting about a year and some other projects allocated to that, we escalated those costs. And we arrived in this bucket of $200 million of other news-related cost. And what we've down here is disposition those inside of this slide. So the new cost of news goes to $1.518 billion. However, United Illuminating, our neighbor in Connecticut, will have essentially about an 8.4% ownership of the assets that are inside of Connecticut. And that would be up to about $69 million. So when you do the math, subtract that from the $1.518 billion, you come up with a new project cost of $1.449 billion with all of the cash flows as you see them right now on that particular slide. So finally, that $84 million on the bottom of the slide, it's been $84 million of projects that are approved, underway and in many cases, some of been have done. The remainder of that $200 million is embedded into the other segments of the project.
Now Chuck talked about the Northern Pass or the HBDC [ph] projects. And we are extremely confident in getting this project done in terms of the projects that we have made with the TSA being signed with HQ. We’ll file that TSA by the end of this month with FERC. We expect to have the order back somewhere around late January, early February. We have filed with the DOE for the presidential permit, which is a permit that you need to cross over into Canada. That permit just does two things because there’s an environmental impact of building the line. It ensures that would align process opens [ph] into another country, that it doesn't cause any undue security from the energy standpoint is to building the line. 
Some other key milestones. We will begin all of our engineering, life long lead time, [indiscernible] conversion station in 2011 and start construction of the project in 2013 for completion in late 2013. The person that is leading that project, Jim Muntz, is our President of transmission [indiscernible] project director for $1.2 billion middle [ph] project is leading that in that effort. All of the roll out that we’ve had so far with business leaders, government leaders in the various communities has been very, very, very positive. So this has been well accepted inside of New Hampshire. So we will continue to give you updates on this. 
If you look at the bottom of that slide, there's an asterisk around the cost of $1.1 billion. And that's really all part of a commitment that we have inside of the transmission services agreement to update the cost of the project within 45 days of signing of the TSA. So we will do that later this year. I'm not trying to signal that the project cost will go up or even change in any way. But if it does, obviously, in a material way, we will advise you of that through the HA [ph] process. So solid year in terms of this project moving forward.
This next slide looks at our CapEx, and it's kind of the look at the past and a look forward. You can see the spend has been up in the past about $2.8 billion, the spend going forward is about $2.8 billion. And again, as Chuck indicated, there really is no CapEx here for the consortium project. In terms of the CapEx here, that could be another additional $1 billion of CapEx that could be coming in the very near future.
First of all, through the bucket moves [ph] by $1.5 billion there, we will have spent about $230 million on news by the end of this year, with about $1.2 billion to go. The Northern Pass, the current NU share of that is $830 million and we will advise you of that in terms of -- once we get into sighting and engineering. In the appendix, an update on the last bucket which it was $845 million. And those are smaller projects, which is spread throughout the new state region and I think the good news there is that 90 percent of those projects either are already inside of the region system plan or they don't need to be inside the regional system plan. That shows that the confidence level of building that $845 million is very, very high. So that's kind of a look, the three-bucket look, very similar to what you’ve seen in the past. 
When you look at the electric distribution generation spend, the distribution has increased $437 million over the previous five-year term [ph] period. And many of the reason why it's increased is because this three-year is $217 million for the rollout of AMI Smart Grid inside of Connecticut Light and Power. And you see that those who are in the 2014, 2015 time frames, the total of the project is nearly about $300 million dollars, about $296 million is estimated to be right now. It also includes $130 million more as part of the rate cases that we have either settled or concluded at CL&P and PSNH. And included in there is up to a total spend of $50 million should we be successful in our rate case at Central Mass Electric.
You have in the past $30 million a year, we propose to spend a total of about $50 million, $20 million more is a result of aging infrastructure and upgrades that are needed. Now in regards to AMI and the additional CapEx spend in Western Mass, to the extent that we do not see rates or revenue recovery father, we will not make those expenditures. We're not going to make them unless we have adequate recovery. The DPUC, that Connecticut DPUC has already started a docket on AMI. The hearings in November, December of this year, and they will render a decision sometime by the end of the first quarter of 2011. As you remember, we have arbitrated for a full rollout of AMI for all 1.2 million customers because we think it’s the least cost approach to rolling out AMI. We've taken the approach to go longer in terms of a rollout because of the issues around U.S. initiatives [ph] on private security and operating protocols, so that's why [indiscernible] just a little bit longer.
We look at generation. Generation is down by about $214 million, that's really for the most part to do with Merrimack. We’ll have contributed [ph] about $150 million to $160 million this year on the Merrimack Scrubber. We reforecasted the price of that again from $4.57 to $4.30. Frankly, we look forward to those units and we probably won't have to spend as much capital as we previously thought. That's your $217 million difference there.
Liquid [ph] gas, for the reasons I indicated before, we see a good growth story there. This five-year look increases by $104 million over the previous five-year look for a total spend of $585 million. And it really centers around four areas. One is running the base of business, the other is just conversion from a lot of customers, about 50% [ph] of the heating in Connecticut is in oil, over 50 percent. A lot of opportunities for natural gas prices in the commodity now and where we think it’ll be for the foreseeable future, the conversions from other gas and also from interruptibles over the firm. We have a large backlog of customers that want to be connected, commercial industrial customers. And so we have a number of projects that would build out supply lines to those areas. And we also have this thing called [inaudible], which is the distribution management program [ph], which is a federally required program to basically take out the old bare steel and [inaudible] piping. So a spend really about [inaudible] on that. Rate base, $714 million, up to $1.1 billion by the end of the five-year planning period, so that's about a 53% increase in rate case [ph], so we really do believe that we can build this company very successfully.
So just for the sake of time, I'm going to curtail [ph] my presentation and turn it over to David McHale, who will take you through the financials.

headline: Northeast Utilities, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Lee, and good morning. I'm to go to speak for just a few moments on business as usual. But business as usual is pretty good these days. We've got third quarter earnings that were released on five, quarter earnings were up 55%. Based on some of
componenttext:
Thank you, Lee, and good morning. I'm to go to speak for just a few moments on business as usual. But business as usual is pretty good these days. We've got third quarter earnings that were released on five, quarter earnings were up 55%. Based on some of the structural trends that we're seeing for the year, we've also increased guidance. Remember, we started this year with a view of midpoint around $1.90 a share, midpoint for this new guidance is $2.15. I'm going to talk a little bit about how that works its way into 2011 as well. 
The cash flow story has always been important for us as a company. It really speaks to the finance-ability of our rate-base plan because of bonus appreciation and a number of really key drivers this year, we're ahead of schedule. We accretively told you that we expected FFO to climb by about $100 million a year. Couple of years from now, we'll be at over $1 billion of FFO compared to maybe two years ago when we were half that. Very, very strong asset of our overall plan. 
In the cornerstone of our stand-alone plan is that rate-based growth that we've gone through, marrying that with the NSTAR plan is going to, I think, address this compelling total return story that Chuck and Tom referred to earlier this morning. And I'm just going to summarize that for you. I won't go through all those details. But first, with the quarter, because there's a couple of things that we want to point out. You see the numbers here on your right, $100.5 million in the quarter for earnings, driven surprisingly by the Distribution business. The Transition business, right on course, actually a little bit ahead of schedule, September is about $2.6 billion, that's up about $140 million over last year. And once we get into this greater Springfield project, that'll drive 2011. But in terms of what's really happening behind the scenes, and it's to be expected, the distribution business is now, particularly coming off [indiscernible] you’re seeing those things earnings being driven. 
And of course, there's a weather effect here. But the to look at what's happening this year, and it’s going work to into our views for both guidance and next year, really good progress around O&M management, extraordinarily good progress around our uncollectible expense relative to expectation, whether it's about $10 million of earnings in this quarter and also the rate cases. If there's a soft spot, and you've seen this, it's around sales. When we reported second quarter and we talked to you in August, we were seeing a little bit of optimism in terms of year-over-year growth. I think April was a good month. May was a good month. June was a little bit a low month, but we've seen some summer doldrums in July and August. Now the real sales, of course, are up 6.5%. But for the quarter, weather-normalized sales were down at about 4.4% and we seemed to re-hit [ph] industrial and commercial. 
Now the good news is, when we look at look at September alone, [indiscernible] with the commercial sector, we see in Connecticut strong export-driven growth. We see an increase in average work week, but no question that we’re not getting the real growth that maybe we saw or maybe held some promise in the summer. We've even seen employment in the region soften a little bit, particularly in Connecticut. So this is something that we'll look at. Now you know from our conversations in the past that some of our states like Connecticut and New Hampshire, 2/3 of our revenue, our distribution revenue, is tied to the fixed component of our rate structure. So while we don't call it outright decoupling, we're collecting a lot of revenues through customer charges and demand charges. So our balance business model is not as sensitive as a unit sales growth, and certainly even for so for 2011, we're not dependent on a recovery in the economy. It certainly helps, but the overall investment to program, I think, weathers some of what we're seeing there.
When you look at these individual components, I won’t spend a great deal of time on this. Yankee Gas [ph] is a little bit different in terms of their sales equation. They are, as Lee suggested, seeing weather-normalized sales growth of about 6%. They had a very mild winter, so their real sales this year is off about 20%. But the real drivers here are, again, the rate cases that we're seeing in Connecticut and in New Hampshire in O&M. Now O&M in particular is driven by real productivity benefits that we're seeing. I don't think these are sort of one-off occurrences. I think you're going to see this as one of the rationales of why we're optimistic about 2010 and 2011. 
Uncollectible expense has been a great story within the story. For the uncollectible expense in the company that is not tracked through our rate, last year, it cost our company's $47 million pretax to hit bottom line. When we started this year, we thought we’d see an improvement. We had built into our plan about $35 million. Right now, we are trending more like $25 million. So good story there, and that will fall right to the bottom line. And I think that also translates into 2011. For PSNH, it's that plus, it's good, HPPC [ph] growth coming out of the Merrimack project.
You've already seen this exhibit, I'm sure. A couple of things I really want to clarify here, I'm sure over-complicated this exhibit by showing you both GAAP and non-GAAP that I mentioned. What's important is the asterisk. We are saying that our guidance this year can be $2.10 to $2.20 per share, that's both GAAP and non-GAAP. And what's happening behind the scenes here is that we have, in this quarter, it's not reflected yet in our financial results, resolved an [indiscernible] tax item that is going to produce what we’re referring to as a nonrecurring gain. You're going to see that in the quarter. It’s worth about $16 million, $0.09 a share. It's not going to happen next year. It's not going to happen in the future. We call that non-recurring. 
We also are going to begin, as well as our partners, to the [ph] transaction cost associated with the merger here in the quarter as well. Those are equal roughly and offsetting, $0.09 gain, $0.07 cost. And so that's why both on a GAAP and non-GAAP, we get back to that $2.10 to $2.20. But when you think about the earnings capability of this company from what we are about those top line. One of the $1.20 for distribution and $1 for the transmission business. Those are little bit ahead of plan. Again, why are they ahead of plan? And plan, by the way, was updated in August. So this is our second time we’ve guided higher. It’s [indiscernible] for sure, but it's the O&M. It's the uncollectibles. It’s the tax benefits that we’ve received as we’re driving down the company's overall effective tax rate.
Now what I don't have on here, that we would’ve showed you last year, is forward guidance. We have stopped short of showing you 2011 guidance, not because we are not confident around 2011, but because we are partnering with NSTAR. They would typically put out guidance when they complete the year and at the turn of the year show you their view of 2011. We're going to do the same. That said, we know where our consensus is, roughly about $2.20 for 2011, maybe $2.21 depending on how you count that out. We think that's conservative, in part because what I'm telling around the structural trends that we see at O&M. We're not going to carry weather forward for sure, but the way that we're managing our business, including, as Lee suggested, all the projects that are now in place. 
So if you think of what’s driving our earnings for 2011, the year was already set off very, very well. Greater Springfield is driving earnings. By the time we finish 2011, that will be over $300 million in rate base alone. The Merrimack Scrubber project, that is driving earnings going into 2011 for the full year of a case, a full year at PSNH rate case. As you know, we're in the middle of a Massachusetts rate case, so all those fundamentals I think, are poised well. Now on the margins, there are things that we are studying pretty hard: sales, pension expense and the like. But I think that’s already dealt in some of my views. So the consensus out there is good, but I think it is conservative. When we report for the full year, we'll give you sort of line by line segment guidance for the take away is. It's been a strong year for us, 2011 is going to be another very, very attractive you overall.
Now on the CapEx, I won't go through all this, but just to summarize what Lee has positioned there. And we've got a little bit of a callout table by segment on the right $6.64 billion. These bars that you see were the year-by-year spending in 2011 through 2015, we have sort of superimposed for you here last year's plan so you can get your model fine-tuned pretty well. And then just to summarize the overall program, again, the cornerstone of the stand-alone plan is this rate-based growth. It adds to another 9.2% overall CAGR. The underlying transmission growth is a double-digit CAGR 10.7%.
Because of the merger, we’re going to stop short of saying what the stand-alone growth is. You know from our discussion and from Tom, and Chuck this morning, we’re at that highest end of 6% to 9%. We are going to stop short of talking about what our stand-alone dividend policy is. It was 50%, now our dividend policy going forward is to drive dividend growth consistent with earnings. We're going to stop short of talking about the overall finance ability. We’re going to give you more definition of what we're doing in 2011. This program will still need some debt financing. Not a problem, we have great access to capital. Regulators are supportive of that. Much of the overall approvals, state-by-state are in place. The one thing that of course is different, there is no equity required to get this plan done. That certainly is beneficial for the numbers overall. And it's also [indiscernible] cash flow profile going forward. 
Now I'm going to pause there and give my partner Jim Judge an opportunity to run through a few slides covering their quarter.

headline: Northeast Utilities, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, David. Good morning, folks. I'm going to finish up, I guess, with about seven or eight slides. And the three takeaways that I’d like you to walk away from my comments are this. First of all, NSTAR has an outstanding track record. I realize th
componenttext:
Thank you, David. Good morning, folks. I'm going to finish up, I guess, with about seven or eight slides. And the three takeaways that I’d like you to walk away from my comments are this. First of all, NSTAR has an outstanding track record. I realize this is actually the utilities [ph] My guess is a lot of you are familiar with the NU story. This is an opportunity to give you some perspective on who the new partner is. The second takeaway is that we just finished yet another very strong quarter, estimates for the quarter, and I’ll provide a little bit of color on these results.
The third message is really to tell you how very excited I am about this strategic combination. And this is really a transaction that makes so much sense on many fronts. What you have here is the best-in-class transmission planer and operator coming together with the best-in-class distribution operator. What you have here is a cash-rich utility coming together with a project-rich utility. What you have here are two top-flight management teams coming together to make an even stronger one. And I often say that the best indication of what a management team is going to do for you in the future is take a look of their track record, their past. These are two companies that have outstanding record in terms of delivering results to shareholders.
Just when you thought you had seen enough Safe Harbor language, here's one more slide. My lawyers, too, wanted me to remind you that we’ll be making some forward-looking statements, and you should and can review any further disclosures in our reports to the SEC.
For those of you who [indiscernible] NSTAR, business philosophy that is actually very simple. We believe that if you deliver excellent customer service, your customers will be happy, customers are happy, your regulators are happy, and when the regulators are happy, financial success usually follows. The model that we’ve followed for several years, expanding on that very first [indiscernible] about customer service and reliability, is really a half-dozen key metrics that gauge the performance of a distribution utility: the number of outages, the length of outages, the call center performance, billing accuracy and timeliness, every single one of those measures is in the top quartile. Many of them in the top percent of the industry. So we have some excellent customer service, excellent customer service track record. It’s no wonder that our JD Power scores, in terms of customer satisfaction, are the highest in the region. And have improved for four straight years. I'm very confident that with this philosophy, [indiscernible] company will be able to do even more.
From a regulatory standpoint, NSTAR has a very, very long history of rate settlements, working effectively with our regulators and long-term settlements in a win for the shareholders as well as the customers. In fact, we look at this as a core competency of our management team. We haven't had a litigated rate increase since 1986. That's 25 years. I see no reason why we can't continue this. Actually, that span of 25 years, it involves six governors, five attorney generals, more than 20 CPC commissioners. So obviously, we've been able to sort of exercise these skills in a number of different regulatory climates. Tom and I have been involved in every one of these negotiations, and I think I'd speak for both of us when I say we have never been more confident about our ability to do yet another settlement in the back end of this rate deal that expires at the end of 2012.
Key element of the NSTAR earnings growth story has been our ability to improve productivity and control costs. You can see that spending in 2009 went down. That was all discretionary nature. These cuts are really never at the expense of customer service and reliability. One Wall Street analyst, who I think is actually here, wrote in the past that “NSTAR's O&M discipline is as unmatched by any utility I can think of,” and the numbers support that.
Over the last many years, we have – our earnings growth is outperforming Philly [ph] peers. In our second quarter report, we did increase the upper end of our guidance range to $2.50. Like David mentioned, we like to exclude from this onetime items. We actually had three onetime items this year that I should note. We earned $1.03 on the sale of [indiscernible] business in the second quarter. We just announced a settlement with the IRS that covered seven years and in the [ph] quarter. And we will have some tax-related expenses in the fourth quarter.
As a result of solid earnings performance, we've been able to increase the dividend 7% last November, the 12th year in a row that we’ve increased the dividend. Our payout ratio continues to be conservative in the low 60s. And we feel very confident, as David mentioned, we have the prospects of, on a combined basis, higher earnings per share growth that will fuel higher dividend growth, and we expected dividend growth to continue to track earnings going forward.
We are particularly proud of the job we’ve done for our shareholders. As this graph shows, our total shareholder return has increased steadily over the past 13 years. $1,000 invested in NSTAR at the start of the period is worth over $5,000 today. Actually, updated for 2010, we've provide shareholders another 18% already this year, so I'm pretty confident we'll be able to say 14 years now and counting. To put that performance in perspective, you won’t be able to find another utility in the country that has more than three consecutive years of positive total shareholder returns.
Also to put it into perspective, we've done a little bit of research, you will find any company in an industry, manufacturing, high-tech, retail, banking, that can match that track record of consistent total shareholder return increases year in, year out.
So while our financial performance has been off the charts, one thing investments are also concerned with is the financial condition of their investment. And this slide says all you need to know about NSTAR. Our financial condition is number one in the industry with the highest credit rating. So a very long record of providing great returns, but also, clearly, a very strong commitment to maintaining excellent credit quality. I think both of those values will continue within the new company.
An update on transmission. Obviously, Mass [ph] Utility is the poster child of transmission development, but I do want point out that NSTAR has doubled its transmission rate base in the past five years. And we have projects in the queue that will allow us to double it again in the next five years. We have basically based [ph] on reliability and capability projects number of year. That's about $100 million a year on average. We are currently licensing a new 345-kV new line over the canal. That's $120 million investment currently before the Energy Facilities Siting Board in Massachusetts. We expect spending will occur in 2011 and '12. We expect that to be in service by year end '12.
Our next two projects, relatively new, we have a circuit reliability project, the 345-kV line into the timeframe 2014, ’15 is expected construction. We also have 115-kV line that we're stalling down in the Mid-Cape that basically will extend the benefit of the line that we have going over the canal. The bottom of bullet [ph] there Northern Pass, Chuck has covered the; Hydro-Québec project, and a number of folks have talked about the potential of accessing that northern New England, the consortium project.
We did just have a great quarter. Released earnings after the market closed Friday. We still have benefited from an 8% growth in sales that reflected the hot weather in the Boston area. In addition to the sales increase from the weather, we did pick up $0.02 from our annual PVR inflation adjustment related to our rate settlement. The lower interest costs compared to a year ago. They gave us $0.03, and we did just execute a share repurchase that, when you compare with last year's numbers, basically provided a $0.03 in earnings. Offsetting those items are items that are in line with our guidance, increased O&M, increased property taxes associated with our capital spending or rate-based growth. Lastly, we did sell the [indiscernible] business, so in this quarter, the absence of earnings associated with that [indiscernible] sale, which is $0.02. 
I do want to take a minute to talk about income tax settlement that you see in the footnotes. It's a positive development. It resolves all outstanding tax issues that we have from 2001 to 2007. What it does free up is a tax refund of $135 million we expect to receive by the end of the year.
That's really it for my overview. I'd now like to turn it back to Tom and Chuck for our closing messages and then, obviously, questions will follow.

headline: Northeast Utilities, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I hope we've convinced you all that we have a very attractive opportunity going forward. With continued very high return profile, we're all on the new NU team excited about the future. We are excited about the opportunities that lay before us, and w
componenttext: Well, I hope we've convinced you all that we have a very attractive opportunity going forward. With continued very high return profile, we're all on the new NU team excited about the future. We are excited about the opportunities that lay before us, and we're all available, everyone you've heard is available to answer any questions you might have.

headline: Northeast Utilities, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2010
componenttextpreview: This release is a very exciting and great transaction, and we hope you saw some of that today, across the whole management team. And as we kind of work that the next three or four days, you’ll have the opportunity to talk with us collectively and indivi
componenttext:
This release is a very exciting and great transaction, and we hope you saw some of that today, across the whole management team. And as we kind of work that the next three or four days, you’ll have the opportunity to talk with us collectively and individually, and I think we'll just see what a tremendous company this is new organization is going to be. 
So thank you again for your attendance, I know it's a little bit early this morning. We wanted to cover a lot of material, so we asked you to do that. Now, I'll turn it over to Jeff.

headline: Northeast Utilities, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2010

componenttext: That category, that potentially leads to the future. Clearly, the Consortium project that we talked about would tie in [indiscernible] both by others and transmissions you see built by us, so I think help resolve some of the [indiscernible] standards going forward. Who knows what the future might bring, I think Lee talked a little bit about some of the solar projects that we’re involved with in Massachusetts. But I think this new company's scale gives us the ability to work together in a way that we haven't to resolve some of the new energy solutions for the regions that are going to be paramount going forward.

headline: Northeast Utilities, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2010
componenttextpreview: From the legal issues, both Massachusetts, it is a holding company, the holding company transaction in only Massachusetts really needs to approve this transaction. Having said that, we've met with the governor and with the PUC [ph] of Connecticut and in h
componenttext: From the legal issues, both Massachusetts, it is a holding company, the holding company transaction in only Massachusetts really needs to approve this transaction. Having said that, we've met with the governor and with the PUC [ph] of Connecticut and in have conversations with the governor in the BBC [ph] Chairman in New Hampshire. They are going to want to stay very actively involved in this and make sure that negotiations are fully represented by the PUC [ph]. I think that’s very appropriate, so we're working with them to make sure they have all the information around this, particular merger as they look forward as to what their obligations are.

headline: Northeast Utilities, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2010

componenttext: The question is the impact of the capital program on overall retail rates over the next five years.

headline: Northeast Utilities, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2010
componenttextpreview: Distribution is just because the price of natural gas, the commodities right now, the energy pushing, the bill has been falling, as an example sale and P [ph] rates will probably fall in January, between 60% to 70%. If you look at the five year going-forw
componenttext: Distribution is just because the price of natural gas, the commodities right now, the energy pushing, the bill has been falling, as an example sale and P [ph] rates will probably fall in January, between 60% to 70%. If you look at the five year going-forward plan for CL&P over the course of the next five years, that adds up to about $11.67 increase to a customer’s bill on a monthly basis, based on 700-kilowatt customer. But each of the companies obviously different because of the different structure and how they procure energy. So it's about a 2% fee over the course of that time, slightly more for the other two electric companies, and just because we’re natural gas on the commodity on the Yankee side, CapEx spending only about a 10% increase over that five-year period.

headline: Northeast Utilities, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2010
componenttextpreview: And I think what we've been saying on the generation fees, which will go to significantly currently about $0.11 on average, it probably goes to the mid $0.09 somewhere. That's the impact on the generation fees. And the question is, relative to consensus o
componenttext: And I think what we've been saying on the generation fees, which will go to significantly currently about $0.11 on average, it probably goes to the mid $0.09 somewhere. That's the impact on the generation fees. And the question is, relative to consensus of about $2.20 a share, what are some of the assumptions in terms of ROEs and so forth?

headline: Northeast Utilities, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2010
componenttextpreview: When you look at the two [indiscernible] CL&P and PSNH and just think about where they're going to end this year, PSNH for all of its business, with the exclusion of transmission, will be in the 9.5% to 10% range, which is a good run rate for them and I s
componenttext: When you look at the two [indiscernible] CL&P and PSNH and just think about where they're going to end this year, PSNH for all of its business, with the exclusion of transmission, will be in the 9.5% to 10% range, which is a good run rate for them and I see that for the driving forward into 2011. CL&P, its new rates are going to work its way in to be in the 7% to 7.5% at year end '10, and as we work our way into '11 and making sure our statement that we made in August, this is a company that should be achieving 9% hopefully a little bit better, we've got some work to do there. But relative to the 7% that we've been earning, this is big year-over-year improvement on a run rate basis.

headline: Northeast Utilities, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2010

componenttext: The question is, going forward, what would the merged company look to in terms of credit rating?

headline: Northeast Utilities, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well you’ve seen already that the agencies have sort of taken some action on this. We have thought all along that this is going to be credit positive for the [indiscernible]. Certainly, that's going to help the hold co. and potentially the operating com
componenttext: Well you’ve seen already that the agencies have sort of taken some action on this. We have thought all along that this is going to be credit positive for the [indiscernible]. Certainly, that's going to help the hold co. and potentially the operating companies and translate into a lower [indiscernible]. That's quite positive. I think you're going to see us make an argument that for NSTAR, the ratings that they have are now are attainable in terms of lowering the risk profile overall. We've seen some of the actions that have taken place. We're going to spend a lot of time said that and have that discussion about what impacts is on NSTAR, but I think there’s an argument that going forward, even without existing ratings profile, they are going to maintain that. Now I’ll allow Jim to add any other color to that, but we're going to have that assumption.

headline: Northeast Utilities, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2010
componenttextpreview: Personally, I guess I would say is I wouldn’t anticipated all three agencies to put us on credit watch. That didn’t happen. So it's a mixed response. We will be spending a lot of time with them, but I agree with David’s comments that an argument can
componenttext: Personally, I guess I would say is I wouldn’t anticipated all three agencies to put us on credit watch. That didn’t happen. So it's a mixed response. We will be spending a lot of time with them, but I agree with David’s comments that an argument can certainly be made that if the credit qualities and fundamentals of NSTAR entities remain intact… Tom talked about the fact that the diversity that we have now, where we’re no longer just a Massachusetts shop, is really a risk factor that the agencies should take into consideration as they do these assessments. So we’re pretty optimistic and bullish about the outcome, the expectation is that Northeast Utilities is about to get a credit uptick out of that for sure.

headline: Northeast Utilities, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2010
